cluster_classes.class_description: How adult butterflies obtain food from flowers, including nectar as a food resource and the proboscis as the specialized feeding structure.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Adult butterflies feed on nectar from flowers using their long, tubular mouthparts called proboscis.

members.entity_description: A sugary liquid in flowers that serves as a food source for adult butterflies.
The long, tubular mouthparts adult butterflies use to feed on nectar.

cluster_classes.class_description: Taxonomic species of butterflies whose traits (e.g., lifespan, coloration, wing patterns) can vary among them.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Different biological species of caterpillars and distinct taxonomic species of butterflies.

members.entity_description: Distinct taxonomic species of butterflies whose traits, such as lifespan, can vary among them.

cluster_classes.class_description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: adult butterflies, including female butterflies that lay eggs on host plants

members.entity_description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.

cluster_classes.class_description: Adult butterflies as whole organisms, representing the adult life stage and endpoint of metamorphosis, regardless of sex.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: adult butterflies, including female butterflies that lay eggs on host plants

members.entity_description: A butterfly, an insect of the order Lepidoptera that undergoes complete metamorphosis through egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult stages.
Adult form that the caterpillar develops into after completing metamorphosis.

cluster_classes.class_description: The adult (imago) stage of butterflies, including newly emerged adults and fully mature winged individuals that are capable of flight, feeding, and reproduction.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: newly emerged adult butterflyâ€¦ moment of beauty and grace in flight

members.entity_description: An adult butterfly immediately after leaving the chrysalis, before its wings have fully expanded and hardened.

The fourth and final life stage of butterflies, when they are winged, sexually mature insects that feed (often on nectar), pollinate, and focus on mating and reproduction, typically living from a few days to a few weeks depending on species.
The fourth and final life cycle stage of a butterfly, when the fully developed adult butterfly emerges from the chrysalis, flies, feeds, mates, and reproduces.

remarks: After moving the Organism-typed entity 'adult butterflies' (Can_9f2a4b9d) out, this class now cleanly represents the conceptual adult life stage (LifeStage-type entities only).

cluster_classes.class_description: Attributes and characteristics specific to the adult (imago) stage of butterflies, such as typical duration of the adult stage and related life-history parameters.

members.entity_description: The duration of the adult stage of a butterfly's life, typically from a few days to a few weeks depending on species.

args.justification: The entity 'adult butterflies' (Can_9f2a4b9d) is typed as an Organism and describes actual adult butterflies as organisms, matching the 'Adult butterflies' class (ClsR_21565432) rather than the conceptual life-stage class (ClsR_8098889a), which should contain LifeStage-type entities.
Unify the class_group with other butterfly life-history and organism classes under a single, coherent umbrella; adult feeding biology is part of butterfly biology and life cycle.

Align 'Butterfly species' with the same overarching butterfly biology and life cycle group to consistently connect taxon-level variation (e.g., lifespan differences) with life-stage concepts and adult traits.
Female butterflies are a sex-specific subset of adult butterflies and fit naturally in the unified 'Butterfly Biology & Life Cycle' group with other adult and reproductive classes.
Adult butterflies as organisms belong in the same overarching group as adult life stages, female butterflies, and their traits, improving schema connectivity.

args.remark: After moving the Organism-typed entity 'adult butterflies' (Can_9f2a4b9d) out, this class now cleanly represents the conceptual adult life stage (LifeStage-type entities only).
args.justification: The adult butterfly life stage is a core component of the butterfly life cycle and should share a unified class_group with related adult-stage and life-history classes.

Butterfly adult stage attributes (e.g., lifespan) are directly tied to the adult life stage and species-level variation, so they should be grouped with other butterfly life-cycle and adult biology classes under a single class_group.

Female butterflies are a sex-specific subset of adult butterflies and fit naturally in the unified 'Butterfly Biology & Life Cycle' group with other adult and reproductive classes.
Adult butterflies as organisms belong in the same overarching group as adult life stages, female butterflies, and their traits, improving schema connectivity.
